articles.headline: How Donald Trump and Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s Unlikely Partnership Took Shape
articles.snippet: The Trump-Kennedy alliance followed a six-week crush of behind-the-scenes discussions, embarrassing missteps, secret meetings and private misgivings.
articles.abstract: The Trump-Kennedy alliance followed a six-week crush of behind-the-scenes discussions, embarrassing missteps, secret meetings and private misgivings.
articles.lead_paragraph: About three hours after former President Donald J. Trump was nearly assassinated, on a Saturday evening in mid-July, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. got a phone call: Would he consider joining forces with Mr. Trump? What about serving as his running mate?
articles.byline: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Biden Plays Second Fiddle to Harris as They Rally for Union Support
articles.snippet: The president introduced his No. 2, Kamala Harris, at a Labor Day event in Pittsburgh as the Democrats campaigned in crucial Midwestern “blue wall” states.
articles.abstract: The president introduced his No. 2, Kamala Harris, at a Labor Day event in Pittsburgh as the Democrats campaigned in crucial Midwestern “blue wall” states.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden gave a demonstration on Monday that the Democratic Party now belongs to Vice President Kamala Harris, stepping to the microphone at a campaign event in Pittsburgh to introduce his No. 2 rather than taking the speaking slot of honor for himself.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Nicholas Nehamas

articles.headline: Netanyahu Stands Firm on Cease-Fire Terms Amid Growing Outrage in Israel
articles.snippet: In his first news conference since the bodies of six killed hostages were recovered, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu refused to budge on his conditions for any truce in Gaza.
articles.abstract: In his first news conference since the bodies of six killed hostages were recovered, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu refused to budge on his conditions for any truce in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brushing aside pleas from allies and the demands of Israeli protesters for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza in exchange for the release of hostages, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday vowed to maintain Israeli control along the border between Egypt and Gaza, a contentious plan that appeared to dim, if not dash, prospects for a truce.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Why It’s So Hard for China to Fix Its Ailing Economy
articles.snippet: A real estate collapse has made consumers cautious and businesses wary, as China confronts a crisis unlike any other since it opened its economy to the world.
articles.abstract: A real estate collapse has made consumers cautious and businesses wary, as China confronts a crisis unlike any other since it opened its economy to the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2004, as China’s economy was emerging as a global force, a group of researchers started conducting nationwide surveys asking Chinese people if they were better off financially than they were five years earlier.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu

articles.headline: Left-Wing Misinformation Is Having a Moment
articles.snippet: America’s right flank remains the chief purveyor of misinformation, but this summer’s political tumult created ideal conditions for falsehoods to spread among progressives.
articles.abstract: America’s right flank remains the chief purveyor of misinformation, but this summer’s political tumult created ideal conditions for falsehoods to spread among progressives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several elected officials, along with a top political aide for the billionaire Reid Hoffman, recently suggested, without proof, that former President Donald J. Trump may have staged an attempt to assassinate him in July.
articles.byline: By Stuart A. Thompson and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: As Israel’s Rifts Widen, Netanyahu Remains Defiant
articles.snippet: In strikes and protests, many Israelis are pushing their government to prioritize the release of hostages above the immediate defeat of Hamas. But Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has refused to change course.
articles.abstract: In strikes and protests, many Israelis are pushing their government to prioritize the release of hostages above the immediate defeat of Hamas. But Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has refused to change course.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Israel’s largest union began a strike on Monday, building on the largest anti-government protests since the start of the war in Gaza, the group hoped to persuade the government to swiftly agree to a cease-fire.

articles.headline: OpenAI, Still Haunted by Its Chaotic Past, Is Trying to Grow Up
articles.snippet: The maker of ChatGPT is struggling to transform itself into a profit-driven company while satisfying worries about the safety of artificial intelligence.
articles.abstract: The maker of ChatGPT is struggling to transform itself into a profit-driven company while satisfying worries about the safety of artificial intelligence.
articles.lead_paragraph: OpenAI, the often troubled standard-bearer of the tech industry’s push into artificial intelligence, is making substantial changes to its management team, and even how it is organized, as it courts investments from some of the wealthiest companies in the world.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Can Democrats Stop the ‘Tax Doom Loop’?
articles.snippet: Democrats are tired of losing to Republicans on tax policy. They’re hoping to mount a comeback next year.
articles.abstract: Democrats are tired of losing to Republicans on tax policy. They’re hoping to mount a comeback next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, Democrats have watched with frustration as tax policy in the United States has settled into a pattern, one that Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat, calls the “tax doom loop.”

articles.headline: How an Ohio Town Landed in the Middle of the Immigration Debate
articles.snippet: Jobs attracted thousands of Haitians to Springfield, and employers were ecstatic. But then an immigrant driver was involved in a fatal school bus crash. And JD Vance entered the fray.
articles.abstract: Jobs attracted thousands of Haitians to Springfield, and employers were ecstatic. But then an immigrant driver was involved in a fatal school bus crash. And JD Vance entered the fray.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been more than a year since the fateful morning last August when, outside Springfield in southwestern Ohio, a minivan veered into oncoming traffic and rammed into a school bus on the first day of class, killing an 11-year-old boy and injuring 23 other children.

articles.headline: Former Volkswagen Chief Executive Faces Trial in Emissions Case
articles.snippet: Nine years after the carmaker admitted to concealing emissions on a massive scale, Martin Winterkorn will be tried in a German court.
articles.abstract: Nine years after the carmaker admitted to concealing emissions on a massive scale, Martin Winterkorn will be tried in a German court.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost nine years after Volkswagen admitted that it had rigged millions of cars to cheat on emissions tests, the company’s former chief executive went on trial Tuesday on charges stemming from the fraud, a vast corporate conspiracy that changed the auto industry.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Tatiana Firsova
